practice.oneSolution.step3.solution.oldText: <par><check><on-true>As usual when solving a product equation, we move the factor in front of <inline-math/> (here <inline-math/>) to the other side, where it will be divided by. practice.oneSolution.step4.problem.oldText: Based on the value of the contents of the square root, determine how many solutions the given equation has.
practice.oneSolution.step4.problem.latestText: Based on the value of the discriminant, determine how many solutions the given equation has.

practice.oneSolution.step4.solution.oldText: <par>When the square root reduces to zero, the plus/minus in the solution vanishes and the equation will have exactly one solution.</par>
practice.oneSolution.step4.solution.latestText: <par>When the square root reduces to zero, the plus/minus in the solution vanishes and the equation will have exactly one solution.</par>

theory.determinant.latestText: <info>You have seen that the number within the square root determines how many solutions the equation has. Because of this, this number <inline-math/> is called the <term>determinant</term> of the equation.</info>

theory.discriminant.latestText: <info>You have seen that the number within the square root determines how many solutions the equation has. Because of this, this number <inline-math/> is called the <term>discriminant</term> of the equation.</info>

theory.steps.oldText: The stepsTo solve a quadratic equation, like , take the following steps.Compare the equation to the standard form to determine , and . If there is a minus sign, the corresponding number should be negative. For our example we have , and .Substitute , and into the general solution . For our example we get .Simplify the root and use the number within it (the determinant) to determine the number of solutions.If the determinant is positive then there are two solutions.If the determinant is negative then there are no solutions.If the determinant is zero then there is exactly one solution.For our example we get so there are two solutions.Simplify the resulting fraction, canceling fraction factors where possible. For our example reduces to .Finally write the two solutions (if they exist) side by side. For our example we get and .
theory.steps.latestText: The stepsTo solve a quadratic equation, like , take the following steps.Compare the equation to the standard form to determine , and . If there is a minus sign, the corresponding number should be negative. For our example we have , and .Substitute , and into the general solution . For our example we get .Simplify the root and use the number within it (the discriminant) to determine the number of solutions.If the discriminant is positive then there are two solutions.If the discriminant is negative then there are no solutions.If the discriminant is zero then there is exactly one solution.For our example we get so there are two solutions.Simplify the resulting fraction, canceling fraction factors where possible. For our example reduces to .Finally write the two solutions (if they exist) side by side. For our example we get and .
